title: Having a really hard day — just need to vent

posts.body:
I'm sitting in my car in the Walgreens parking lot crying and I don't know where else to put this.

I drove across town during my lunch break to get my mom's groceries. She has vascular dementia and she's been having a hard week. I thought I was being thoughtful. I got her favorite crackers, the good bread, everything on her list.

I get there and she screams at me. SCREAMS. For twenty minutes. Because I got the store brand saltines instead of the name brand. Her aide was standing right there. I just stood there taking it while this woman who used to be my mother called me thoughtless and selfish and said I don't care about her.

I know it's the disease. I KNOW. But she grabbed the crackers and threw them on the floor and something in me just broke.

I love her. And I don't like her right now. And I feel horrible for saying that.

I have to go back to work in 15 minutes. I don't know how I'm going to pretend to be a functional human.

Teresa. Oh sweetheart.

You are not horrible. You drove across town on your lunch break to bring her groceries. That's love, even when it gets thrown back at you.

You're allowed to love someone and not like them right now. You're allowed to miss who she used to be. You're allowed to be angry and sad and exhausted all at once.

Take a few more minutes in that car if you can. Cry. Then go back to work and do the best you can. That's all any of us can do.

The crackers don't matter. You showing up matters. Even when she can't see it.

I've had the parking lot crying sessions. More than I want to admit.

Something my therapist told me that I come back to: "You can love someone and not like them in that moment." That doesn't make you a bad daughter. It makes you a human being dealing with an inhumanly hard situation.

The disease has taken your real mom. You're grieving her while still caring for her body. That's an impossible position to be in and you're doing it anyway.

Give yourself grace. Even when it's hard to find.

The crackers. Always something so small that breaks us.

My dad has Lewy Body dementia and some days the meanness is brutal. Last week he told me I was stealing from him. His own daughter, who quit her job to care for him. I know it's the disease but I cried for an hour.

I've started writing myself notes on the hard days: "This is the disease talking, not Dad. I'm a good daughter. I'm doing my best." Sometimes I read them when I need a reminder.

You ARE a good daughter. She won't remember the crackers. But the love behind your visit still matters—to her on some level, and to you.

Thank you all. I'm still in the parking lot. I'm probably going to be late back to work and I don't even care right now.

"You can love someone and not like them in that moment." I needed to hear that.

"Grieving her while still caring for her body." That's exactly it. The mom I knew would never have spoken to me like that. That person is already gone, even though she's still physically here.

I'm going to dry my eyes and go back. Knowing you all are out there dealing with your own cracker moments helps more than you know.

Just seeing this now. Teresa, I'm so sorry.

I want to point out something though: you came here instead of taking it out on yourself or stuffing it down. You reached out. That's a healthy coping skill, even when it doesn't feel like one.

I hope the afternoon was bearable. We're here.

Made it through the day. Barely. I messed up a report because I couldn't concentrate but my boss didn't notice.

My husband had dinner ready when I got home and didn't ask any questions when I crawled straight into bed at 7:30.

I don't have anything wise to say. I'm just tired. Tomorrow might be better. Or it might not. I'll deal with it then.

Thank you for being here. This community is a lifeline when the people in my actual life don't understand.

You don't need to be wise. You just need to get through.

Bed at 7:30 sounds exactly right. Rest.

We're here tomorrow too.
